howItWorks.title: How EOQ Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: EOQ = sqrt(2 × Annual Demand × Order Cost / Holding Cost)
howItWorks.explanation: Economic Order Quantity finds the optimal order size that minimizes total inventory costs. It balances ordering costs (which decrease with larger orders) against holding costs (which increase with larger inventory). The EOQ is where these two cost curves intersect.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Demand Variability
commonMistakes.description: EOQ assumes constant demand. For variable demand, add safety stock and consider seasonal adjustments.

commonMistakes.title: Underestimating Holding Costs
commonMistakes.description: Include all costs: storage space, insurance, shrinkage, obsolescence, capital tied up, and handling.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Quantity Discounts
commonMistakes.description: EOQ doesn't account for volume discounts. Compare total cost at EOQ to cost at discount price breaks.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Lead Time
commonMistakes.description: EOQ determines how much to order, but reorder point depends on lead time. Calculate both together.

faqs.question: What is Economic Order Quantity?
faqs.answer: EOQ is the optimal order size that minimizes total inventory costs (ordering + holding). It's where the cost of placing orders equals the cost of holding inventory.

faqs.question: What costs are included in ordering cost?
faqs.answer: Fixed costs per order: purchase order processing, shipping/freight, receiving and inspection, invoice processing. Does not include the product cost itself.

faqs.question: What costs are included in holding cost?
faqs.answer: Annual cost to store one unit: storage space, insurance, taxes, obsolescence, shrinkage, opportunity cost of capital. Typically 15-30% of item value.

faqs.question: Does EOQ work for all products?
faqs.answer: Best for stable, continuous demand items. Less suitable for seasonal products, new products, or items with highly variable demand.

faqs.question: How often should I recalculate EOQ?
faqs.answer: When demand, ordering costs, or holding costs change significantly. At minimum, review annually or when making major supply chain changes.

howItWorks.title: How Inventory Turnover Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Inventory Turnover = Cost of Goods Sold / Average Inventory
howItWorks.explanation: Inventory turnover measures how many times a company sells and replaces its inventory during a period. Higher turnover indicates efficient inventory management - products sell quickly without sitting in warehouses. Lower turnover may indicate overstocking or slow sales.

commonMistakes.title: Using Revenue Instead of COGS
commonMistakes.description: Always use Cost of Goods Sold, not revenue. Revenue includes profit margin and distorts the ratio.

commonMistakes.title: Point-in-Time Inventory
commonMistakes.description: Use average inventory (beginning + ending / 2), not just ending inventory. Seasonal variations affect point-in-time values.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Seasonality
commonMistakes.description: Seasonal businesses may have different turnover at different times. Analyze full-year and compare periods consistently.

commonMistakes.title: Cross-Industry Comparisons
commonMistakes.description: Turnover varies dramatically by industry. Compare only within your sector for meaningful benchmarking.

faqs.question: What is a good inventory turnover ratio?
faqs.answer: Depends on industry. Grocery: 12-15x. Apparel: 4-6x. Furniture: 3-4x. Electronics: 6-8x. Compare to your specific industry average.

faqs.question: How do I calculate days to sell inventory?
faqs.answer: DSI = 365 / Inventory Turnover. If turnover is 6x, DSI = 365/6 = 61 days average to sell inventory.

faqs.question: Is higher or lower inventory turnover better?
faqs.answer: Generally higher is better (efficient inventory management), but too high may mean stockouts. Balance efficiency with service levels.

faqs.question: How can I improve inventory turnover?
faqs.answer: Reduce slow-moving items, improve demand forecasting, negotiate smaller/frequent deliveries, run promotions on old stock, and optimize reorder points.

faqs.question: What if my turnover is too low?
faqs.answer: Low turnover ties up cash and increases holding costs. Review product mix, identify obsolete inventory, consider markdowns, and improve sales efforts.
